messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learning Visual Locomotion with Cross-Modal Supervision

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this work, we show how to learn a visual walking policy that only uses a monocular RGB camera and proprioception. Since simulating RGB is hard, we necessarily have to learn vision in the real world. We start with a blind walking policy trained in simulation. This policy can traverse some terrains in the real world but often struggles since it lacks knowledge of the upcoming geometry. This can be resolved with the use of vision. We train a visual module in the real world to predict the upcoming terrain with our proposed algorithm Cross-Modal Supervision (CMS). CMS uses time-shifted proprioception to supervise vision and allows the policy to continually improve with more real-world experience. We evaluate our vision-based walking policy over a diverse set of terrains including stairs (up to 19cm high), slippery slopes (inclination of 35∘), curbs and tall steps (up to 20cm), and complex discrete terrains. We achieve this performance with less than 30 minutes of real-world data. Finally, we show that our policy can adapt to shifts in the visual field with a limited amount of real-world experience.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Rma: Rapid motor adaptation for legged robots",
        "Learning quadrupedal locomotion over challenging terrain",
        "Understanding the roles of vision in the control of human locomotion",
        "Strategies for dynamic stability during adaptive human locomotion",
        "Visual space perception and visually directed action.",
        "Binocular vision and the control of foot placement during walking in natural terrain",
        "Crawling and walking infants see the world differently",
        "Towards robust monocular depth estimation: Mixing datasets for zero-shot cross-dataset transfer",
        "Multiple view geometry in computer vision.",
        "Legged locomotion in challenging terrains using egocentric vision",
        "Learning robust perceptive locomotion for quadrupedal robots in the wild",
        "Learning high-speed flight in the wild",
        "Prism adaptation for spatial neglect after stroke: translational practice gaps",
        "Minimizing energy consumption leads to the emergence of gaits in legged robots",
        "The Staircase: Studies of Hazards, Falls, and Safer Design.",
        "Per-contact iteration method for solving contact dynamics",
        "Shufflenet v2: Practical guidelines for efficient cnn architecture design",
        "Helmholtz’s treatise on physiological optics.",
        "Compliant quadruped locomotion over rough terrain",
        "Rapidly exponentially stabilizing control lyapunov functions and hybrid zero dynamics",
        "Piecewise linear spine for speed–energy efficiency trade-off in quadruped robots",
        "Implementation of trot-to-gallop transition and subsequent gallop on the MIT cheetah i",
        "Dynamic locomotion and whole-body control for quadrupedal robots",
        "Learning, planning, and control for quadruped locomotion over challenging terrain",
        "Dynamically diverse legged locomotion for rough terrain",
        "Practice makes perfect: An optimization-based approach to controlling agile motions for a quadruped robot",
        "Bayesian optimization for learning gaits under uncertainty",
        "Learning agile and dynamic motor skills for legged robots",
        "The stanford LittleDog: A learning and rapid replanning approach to quadruped locomotion",
        "Optimization and learning for rough terrain legged locomotion",
        "Learning to walk in minutes using massively parallel deep reinforcement learning",
        "Deepgait: Planning and control of quadrupedal gaits using deep reinforcement learning",
        "Vision-aided dynamic quadrupedal locomotion on discrete terrain using motion libraries",
        "Collision-free mpc for legged robots in static and dynamic scenes",
        "Coupling vision and proprioception for navigation of legged robots",
        "Online planning for autonomous running jumps over obstacles in high-speed quadrupeds",
        "Learning to jump from pixels",
        "Visual-locomotion: Learning to walk on complex terrains with vision",
        "Learning vision-guided quadrupedal locomotion end-to-end with cross-modal transformers",
        "Haptic terrain classification for legged robots",
        "Terrain classification and negotiation with a walking robot",
        "Deep spatiotemporal models for robust proprioceptive terrain classification",
        "The effect of motor action and different sensory modalities on terrain classification in a quadruped robot running with multiple gaits",
        "Integrated ground reaction force sensing and terrain classification for small legged robots",
        "Where should i walk? predicting terrain properties from images via self-supervised learning",
        "Real-time optimal navigation planning using learned motion costs",
        "Path planning with local motion estimations",
        "Learning ground traversability from simulations",
        "Badgr: An autonomous self-supervised learning-based navigation system",
        "Learning long-range perception using self-supervision from short-range sensors and odometry"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learning Visual Locomotion with Cross-Modal Supervision, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
